title: Stored XSS at APM transaction map (transactionName field)
vulnerability_information:
Hey team,

You've recently fixed my previous report about transaction map stored XSS (#549084) and the fix is correct, I wasn't successful with finding a bypass.

But I've discovered another vulnerable transaction map field `transactionName`. An attacker can inject a payload inside this field and then, when the transaction map is retrieved, the following response is got from webserver:

```html
Thanks for being a beta customer for the transaction map. We'd love...
...
<script>
  RPM.initCatMap({
    url: "/accounts/2385914/applications/173790979/cat_maps/5b225765625472616e73616374696f6e2f46756e6374696f6e2f746f726e61646f2e7765623a4572726f7248616e646c65725c222d616c65727428292d5c222e676574222c22225d",
    applicationName: "</script>",
    transactionName: "/tornado.web:ErrorHandler"-alert()-".get",
   ...
</script>
```

As you can see, the quotes inside the transactionName field are unescaped, so the payload fires.

##Steps to reproduce:
To reproduce an issue, your malicious APM app should send the transaction info with edited (infected) transaction name. I suggest to use the python NR agent for this.
1) Install python requirements with:
```bash
sudo pip install tornado requests newrelic
```
2) Download my specially crafted (malicious) python webserver from here: {F547749}
If you look at this file content, you will see that every transaction name is changed manually to `"-alert(document.domain)-"`
3) Download the "newrelic.ini" I've used while testing from here: {F547750}
4) Put them all into the same directory
5) Edit newrelic.ini and change the `license_key` to your own
6) Run the app with
```bash
NEW_RELIC_CONFIG_FILE=newrelic.ini newrelic-admin run-program python tornado_server.py
```
7) Navigate a couple of times to this app port using your browser, you will see the `Hello world` if everything is OK
8) Wait a little, then navigate to APM -> `app2` application -> Transactions -> `/"-alert(document.domain)-" ` -> Transaction map
9) Make sure the payload fires
{F547757}

###Video-PoC
{F547760}

## Impact

Any "User" to Admin/Owner stored xss
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

You've recently fixed my previous report about transaction map stored XSS (#549084) and the fix is correct, I wasn't successful with finding a bypass.

But I've discovered another vulnerable transaction map field transactionName. An attacker can inject a payload inside this field and then, when the transaction map is retrieved, the following response is got from webserver:

Thanks for being a beta customer for the transaction map. We'd love...
...
<script>
  RPM.initCatMap({
    url: "/accounts/2385914/applications/173790979/cat_maps/5b225765625472616e73616374696f6e2f46756e6374696f6e2f746f726e61646f2e7765623a4572726f7248616e646c65725c222d616c65727428292d5c222e676574222c22225d",
    applicationName: "</script>",
    transactionName: "/tornado.web:ErrorHandler"-alert()-".get",
   ...
</script>

As you can see, the quotes inside the transactionName field are unescaped, so the payload fires.

Steps to reproduce:

To reproduce an issue, your malicious APM app should send the transaction info with edited (infected) transaction name. I suggest to use the python NR agent for this.
1) Install python requirements with:

sudo pip install tornado requests newrelic

2) Download my specially crafted (malicious) python webserver from here: tornado_server.py (F547749)
If you look at this file content, you will see that every transaction name is changed manually to "-alert(document.domain)-"
3) Download the "newrelic.ini" I've used while testing from here: newrelic.ini (F547750)
4) Put them all into the same directory
5) Edit newrelic.ini and change the license_key to your own
6) Run the app with

NEW_RELIC_CONFIG_FILE=newrelic.ini newrelic-admin run-program python tornado_server.py

7) Navigate a couple of times to this app port using your browser, you will see the Hello world if everything is OK
8) Wait a little, then navigate to APM -> app2 application -> Transactions -> /"-alert(document.domain)-" -> Transaction map
9) Make sure the payload fires

Video-PoC

Impact

Any "User" to Admin/Owner stored xss

activities.message: Hey @skavans, I'm working on reproducing this. However, because you are using a lot of your own code. This is taking awhile. Be patient with me.
activities.markdown_message: Hey @skavans, I'm working on reproducing this. However, because you are using a lot of your own code. This is taking awhile. Be patient with me.

activities.message: Hey @jmcaleer, yes, the exploitation is quite tricky, so I’m waiting patiently :)
activities.markdown_message: Hey @jmcaleer, yes, the exploitation is quite tricky, so I’m waiting patiently :)

activities.message: Hey, @skavans! I was able to reproduce this. Let me get back to you shortly about triage!
activities.markdown_message: Hey, @skavans! I was able to reproduce this. Let me get back to you shortly about triage!

activities.message: I downgraded the severity of this report to a `Medium` due to the fact that the transaction maps is not a frequently used feature and thus would require a malicious insider, social engineering, and/or phishing in order to have the XSS pop. Thus, it fits nicely into the `Cross-site scripting (XSS)` category.
activities.markdown_message: I downgraded the severity of this report to a Medium due to the fact that the transaction maps is not a frequently used feature and thus would require a malicious insider, social engineering, and/or phishing in order to have the XSS pop. Thus, it fits nicely into the Cross-site scripting (XSS) category.

activities.message: @jmcaleer, my previous transaction map stored xss report #549084 was awarded with a full price ($2.5k), so why does it differ now? I don’t see at your policy that some “not frequently used” application parts bugs are payed lower than other.
activities.markdown_message: @jmcaleer, my previous transaction map stored xss report #549084 was awarded with a full price ($2.5k), so why does it differ now? I don’t see at your policy that some “not frequently used” application parts bugs are payed lower than other.

activities.message:
This XSS can affect other users, it is "user to admin".
I understand that the severity level can be downgraded in a case where for instance some extraordinary actions should be made by victim to be exploited, but this case is a pretty classic stored XSS with no any user interaction required.
activities.markdown_message:
This XSS can affect other users, it is "user to admin".
I understand that the severity level can be downgraded in a case where for instance some extraordinary actions should be made by victim to be exploited, but this case is a pretty classic stored XSS with no any user interaction required.

activities.message:
It seems my coworker must have given you a bonus for the last one! Inconsistencies in bounty and severity rewarding can be frustrating, and I'm sorry for that. However, we do not want to fall into a pattern of rewarding too much or too little, simply because we've rewarded it in the past.

Our policy states: 

{F548624}

The transaction maps page that shows the alert box cannot be reached via a URL. Thus, the user has to navigate to the page. More over, a user is highly unlikely to navigate to this page without social engineering because this is not an often used feature and has been replaced for over a year according to its documentation: https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apm/transactions/cross-application-traces/viewing-cross-application-traces.

For those reasons, I do not find this XSS to likely be exploited. I understand that it can affect other users, but what is making me consider this a typical XSS (rather than "likely to affect other users") is the user interaction + the likelihood of a victim going to the page being mitigating factors.
activities.markdown_message:

Our policy states:

The transaction maps page that shows the alert box cannot be reached via a URL. Thus, the user has to navigate to the page. More over, a user is highly unlikely to navigate to this page without social engineering because this is not an often used feature and has been replaced for over a year according to its documentation: https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apm/transactions/cross-application-traces/viewing-cross-application-traces.

For those reasons, I do not find this XSS to likely be exploited. I understand that it can affect other users, but what is making me consider this a typical XSS (rather than "likely to affect other users") is the user interaction + the likelihood of a victim going to the page being mitigating factors.

@jmcaleer,

It can be reached by an URL. In my case this URL is

https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/2385914/applications/173878881/transactions#id=5b225765625472616e73616374696f6e2f46756e6374696f6e2f5c222d616c65727428646f63756d656e742e646f6d61696e292d5c22222c22225d&tab-transaction-5b225765625472616e73616374696f6e2f46756e6374696f6e2f5c222d616c65727428646f63756d656e742e646f6d61696e292d5c22222c22225d=catmap-5b225765625472616e73616374696f6e2f46756e6374696f6e2f5c222d616c65727428646f63756d656e742e646f6d61696e292d5c22222c22225d

activities.message: You can obtain this URL for your own infected transaction map if you navigate to it, close the alert box and then copy the current URL.
activities.markdown_message: You can obtain this URL for your own infected transaction map if you navigate to it, close the alert box and then copy the current URL.

activities.message: Tested it again and can definitely reach it from a URL. That's my bad! So sorry. I'm going to give you a bonus of $1750 because while it still requires social engineering, it's definitely less.
activities.markdown_message: Tested it again and can definitely reach it from a URL. That's my bad! So sorry. I'm going to give you a bonus of $1750 because while it still requires social engineering, it's definitely less.

activities.message: @jmcaleer Thank you for always being fair!
activities.markdown_message: @jmcaleer Thank you for always being fair!

activities.message:
Hey @skavans !

You'll find that the three year old Beta map features have been removed entirely! That makes this finally resolved. Thank you for your patience and finding all these issues, it helped us to shut down something that was not even used.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @skavans !

You'll find that the three year old Beta map features have been removed entirely! That makes this finally resolved. Thank you for your patience and finding all these issues, it helped us to shut down something that was not even used.
